div1.p: The original letter, from Ohio, inquires after a woman and her children living in Augusta County whose husband lives in Ohio. The letter asks about the possibilty of the family coming to Ohio to be reunited. The attached endorsements describe the situation of Catharine Crawford White, and the possibility of procuring Bureau support for her transport.

War Dept, Bureau R F & A Lands
Washington Oct 16th 1868.
Respectfully referred to Genl O. Brown Asst Comr, Va for investigation and recommendation. The writer has been informed of this reference.
By order of
Maj. Genl O.O. Howard
F.D. Seward A.A.A.Genl.

Bureau R.F. & A.L.
Hd. Qrs. Asst. Comr. Dist. Va
Richmond, Va. Oct. 19th/68
Respectfully referred to John A. McDonnell Sub Asst Comr 9th Sub Dist for investigation and report.
By order of the Asst Comr
Will A. Coulter
Bvt. Capt. USA, A.A.A.Genl.

Bureau R. F. & A. L.
Head Qrs 9th S.D. Va
Winchester, Oct 21.68
Respectfully returned to Roswell Waldo A.S.A.C. 4th Division for investigation and report
John A. McDonnell
Sub Asst Comr

Bureau R.F. and A.L.
4th Division, 9th Sub Dist. Va.
Stuanton, Va Oct 24 1868
Respectfully returned to Jno A. McDonnell Sub Asst Comr 9th Sub Dist Va, with the following information viz:
Beverly White's wife, Catharine Crawford White and her two (2) children, Jenny and Hannah, aged respectively 15 and 7 years, are at present living with their former Master, James W. Crawford near Mt. Meridian Augusta Co Va. Catharine is considered a good servant, but on account of her incumbrance, both children being entirely dependent, the elder a cripple and badly deformed, she could not, probably, secure another place in this neighborhood where she would be able to support her children by her labor, her only resource, and if Mr. Crawford should discharge her, as he contemplates, in order to secure another servant without such incumbrance, she would be left entirely or at least partially dependent on the Government for support. Her husband has promised to furnish her with sufficient funds to pay her car fare to Springfield O. but has not yet done so, if however, she should receive it, in my opinion, she right to retain the same to meet any exigency that might arise while enroute, for on account of her age, ignorance and inexperience in traveling she might meet with some unforseen trouble or delay enroute.
If the Bureau concludes to furnish her the necessary transportation, I would respectfully suggest that she be started by Stage from Mt. Sidney to Winchester, thence by Railroad to Springfield via Columbus & London.
Roswell Waldo
A.S.A.Comr
4th Div. 9th Sub Dist Va.

H'd Q'rs Asst Comr
Bureau of R.F. & A.L.
Richmond, Va. Oct. 29th 1868
Respectfully returned to John A. McDonnell Sub Asst Comr, 9th Sub Dist. Does not Augusta County provide for its paupers? if so, why does Mr. Waldo, A.S.A.C. state that this family will become dependent on the Bureau, if they remain in that County?
By order of the Asst Comr
Will A. Coulter
Bvt. Capt. USA A.A.A.Genl.

Bureau R.F. & A.L. HdQrs 9th Sub Dist. Va
Winchester, Oct. 31.68
Respectfully returned to R. Waldo, A.S.A.Comr, 4th Div. for the explanation required by endorsement of Asst. Comr. of 29 inst.
John A. McDonnell
Sub Asst Comr

Bureau R.F. and A.L.
4th Division, 9th Sub Dist. Va.
Staunton, Va. Nov. 4 1868
Respectfully returned to Jno. A. McDonnell, Sub Asst. Comr. 9th Sub Dist.
Augusta County does support an Institution for the relief of its paupers. But many suffering freedpeople are not inmates of the Institution that, perhaps should be. It is the class of person who are unable to provide for themselves, all the necessaries of life that apply to this office for aid. And as the Bureau has provided clothing for distribution among destitute freedpeople, of this Division, the same has been given these applicants. It was not the expectation that the within named family would become so indigent as to be dependent on the County for support if they remained here, that prompted me to make the statement contained in my endorsement of 24th ult. ("would become 'partially' dependent on Govt for support") - but that Catharine, if discharged by her present Employer, would be unable to support her dependent family without aid from some source & as the Bureau is the resort of all freedpeople in distress it is reasonable to suppose she would come too, and impartiality in the administration of the duties of this office would require its incumbent to provide for this family, as well as others to the extent allowed & granted by the Bureau. To this degree would this family become dependent on the Bureau for support.
Roswell Waldo
A.S.A.Comr
4th Div. 9th Sub Dist. Va

H'd Q'rs Ass't Com'r Dist of Va.
Bureau of R.F. & A. L.
Richmond, Va. Nov. 9th 1868
Respectfully returned to Maj. Genl. O.O. Howard, Comr, disapproved. It does not appear that the parties herein named, are dependent upon the Bureau for support, or liable to become so, for a considerable length of time.
O.Brown
Asst. Comr.

div1.head:
Post Office Maj Genl O.O. Howard
Commissioner Bureau R. F. & A. L.
Washington DC
div1.p: One Beverly White, colored, living in this place for several years past, asks me to write you to know whether transportation could be furnished by the Bureau to his wife & 2 children living at Mount Meridian Augusta County Virginia to this place. He left there seven years ago and now wants to get his family to this place, his home. Will you please advise me what the Bureau can do for him & oblige
